header_summary:
Moonsettler's proposal introduces `OP_PAIRCOMMIT` to Tapscript, enhancing Lightning Network (LN) efficiency through a new opcode aimed at facilitating rebindable channels within various covenant constructions. This addition seeks to optimize LN-Symmetry by minimizing SHA256 iterations, especially beneficial in unilateral close scenarios, and repurposes an existing opcode for backward compatibility. The proposal, supported by contributors such as Jeremy Rubin and Anthony Towns, is documented in a [GitHub gist](https://gist.github.com/moonsettler/d7f1fb88e3e54ee7ecb6d69ff126433b) and a [bitcoin/bips PR](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips).

Andrew Poelstra highlights the challenges of maintaining an accessible Bitcoin email archive due to the decentralized nature of the community. The lack of a centralized entity for archive management underscores the reliance on community volunteers and the inherent risks, such as cyber threats, faced by such decentralized solutions. This discussion points to the broader tech community's dilemma of ensuring the longevity of valuable digital archives amidst financial, technical, and security challenges, as seen in the [gnusha.org archives](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CABaSBaz13bUoHCupXYhmX+yS0dn89f80yx8ZD3uO5-1RiLZJCQ@mail.gmail.com/T/#ma5834901b1f12eaea319b5ba6982357905be04bd).

Ethan Heilman delves into the specifics of transaction grinding in Bitcoin, explaining the process and its significance for maintaining transaction security. He clarifies that the deterministic nature of generating specific transaction values through grinding does not give attackers an advantage, thus ensuring the integrity of transactions against potential security threats. His explanation provides insight into the ongoing efforts to understand and mitigate vulnerabilities within Bitcoin's system, as shared in a [gnusha.org discussion](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CAEM=y+W2jyFoJAq9XrE9whQ7EZG4HRST01TucWHJtBhQiRTSNQ@mail.gmail.com/T/#m4278899c5d3fed1b1537d899f7445bed0389bcf6).

Radpool's innovative approach to combat mining centralization through a syndicate of Mining Service Providers (MSPs) offers a solution that decentralizes block template generation. By utilizing Discreet Log Contracts (DLCs) for miner payouts and fostering a competitive market for pool fees, Radpool aims to bridge the gap between centralized and peer-to-peer pools. This initiative not only encourages network growth but also enhances stability and reliability within the mining ecosystem, as outlined in the [Radpool discussion](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/radpool-decentralised-mining-pool-with-futures-contracts-for-payouts/1262).

active_posts.title: Multi-byte opcodes
active_posts.summary:
- A novel solution suggests introducing multi-byte opcodes to expand Bitcoin's functionality.

active_posts.title: A Fast, Scalable Protocol For Resolving Lightning Payments
active_posts.summary:
- The OPR protocol enables quick, small payment resolutions in the Lightning network, enhancing security.
- It implements a novel mechanism deterring dishonesty, ensuring transactions are settled without on-chain costs.
- By supporting seamless integration with existing technologies, the OPR protocol offers scalability improvements.

active_posts.title: Expanding on BOLT12
active_posts.summary:
- BOLT12's merger into the main repository introduces advancements and prompts enhancement discussions.
- Proposed enhancements include a `user` field in `invoice_request` and a `refund_invoice_required` field.
- Suggestions also focus on an `offer_max_amount` limit and implementing an expiration mechanism for `invoice_request`s.

active_posts.title: Channel depletion, LN Topology, Cycles and rational behavior of nodes
active_posts.summary:
- Investigation explains Lightning Network's channel depletion via economic rationality and network topology.
- Research offers tools for liquidity estimation and fee optimization, revealing nodes' behavior impacts on network.
- Future directions include strategies for liquidity management and predicting liquidity for payment routing optimization.

today_in_history_posts.title: OP_CHECKWILDCARDSIGVERIFY or "Wildcard Inputs" or "Coalescing Transactions"
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- A new opcode, OP_CHECKWILDCARDSIGVERIFY, is proposed to address small UTXOs and high fees.
- It creates a wildcard input for transactions, ignoring the input value to reduce fees.
- This solution coalesces UTXOs into a single output, potentially lowering transaction costs.

today_in_history_posts.title: Lightning, the death of BIP62, and Segregated Witness
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Rusty Russell identified anchor malleability as a problem in a lightning variant.
- He considered multiple solutions but chose to rely on Segregated Witness.
- This choice aligns with simplifying lightning code and benefits Bitcoin and smart contracts.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin aims to support 1 billion weekly users via 50,000 off-chain "bitcoin banks." - These entities will enhance scalability by handling transactions through methods like federated sidechains.
- New tech and protocols, like OP_VAULT and Lightning Network, are key to Bitcoin's scalability and security.
